data.text: How to Set Up Camp in Pouring Rain?

Sometimes, there is no choice, and being wet and cold is no fun, plus all my stuff also gets wet. How do you set up camp in a pooring rain ? And also, how do you pack and go in a pooring rain ? How about in hard winds ? Any tricks ? What do you do when setting/putting down the tent (other than getting wet :) )?
Setting up? No great ideas just luck. Packing up, just pack fast and ride and shake out gear and repack on morning or lunch break.
data.author: Bravos Louis

data.text: Wear waterproof clothing and put the tent at the top of your rucksack
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: If it's really pouring, wait a while. Tent design can make a significant difference too. I have a Big Sky Revolution tent where the outer (fly) hangs from the poles and the inner hangs from the fly. Most of the time I leave the inner and fly connected and they pitch together - if it's raining, only the fly gets wet when pitching (setting up) the tent, the inner stays (mostly!) dry. If the fly is wet (or it's still raining) when packing down the tent, I unclip the (dry) inner from the fly first and pack it away. Then under the shelter if the (wet) fly pack everything into panniers and dress for the conditions(!) Then unclip the (wet) fly from the poles and pack these where they won't get the dry stuff wet. There's usually a chance during the day to lay out the fly to dry. The next time setting up the tent is a little different. Clip the (wet or dry) fly to the poles, then clip the (dry) inner to the fly. Hopefully you can make sense of all that!

data.author: Patrick Snyder

data.text: 1. If it's a true downpour, wait and see if it will stop or lighten. 2. Watch how the water is moving across the camping area, and choose a place that isn't in the path of much water. 3. Always use a groundcloth, and use extra tent pegs to raise the edge on the uphill side to direct water around the tent, instead of straight under it. 4. If you have one, put up a tarp over where you're going to put up the tent first, before you start working, to help avoid soaking the tent while putting it up. 5. Use the rain fly, if you have one! In future: 1. Practice putting up the tent so you can do it really quickly. Ideally, practice in the dark with headlamps so you can do it even if you end up waiting out a storm until the evening. 2. Always pack extra tarps and tent pegs (if you're not in a situation where weight matters).

data.text: Start with waterproof panniers. Have your gear packed according to need. So your tent should be on top your rack or top of pannier ( which I personally don't like). Maybe include a lite weight tarp you can set-up 1st. Wait awhile and see if the storm passes. Lastly, learn to set your tent up quickly and have only it exposed to the weather. Here's a trick I've used a few times...if you have a freestanding tent and there's a picnic pavillion near your campsite set the tent up in the pavillion and then bring it outside already erected. Saves some wet time!
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: Start with your rain fly system so you can at least get that part done & avoid further wetness. This is true regardless of whether your rain fly is grounded (tent) or hung (hammock). After the rain fly is up, then you can decide what to do under it, whether chores or set up your sleeping system.

data.text: As much as I am able to camp in adverse weather, these are the times when maybe you should consider alternatives like camping under a picnic shelter or even a hotel. The idea is to enjoy your trip not suffer. My tent itself does not absorb water so even if the inside fabric gets slightly damp after being packed up wet, so it isn't a big deal. All my clothes, sleeping bags etc. are packed in compression dry bags so they stay dry. Good clothing choices help too, avoid materials like cotton. Stop and put waterproof layers on when it starts to rain. Keep the layers close to your skin dry.
